titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:15— Cloudy. Rain. Appraisement of Woodlots.

Captain Riley was here and shewed me Letters from two of his friends in Connecticut, expressing the wish that in the expected vacancy of the Collector’s Office at Middletown, he might receive the appointment. Captain Riley has formed a Settlement at the Western corner of the State of Ohio, which has been partially successful, but his health has not resisted the climate, and he is obliged to pass the latter summer and first autumnal Months North of his Residence— Mr French surveyed last Winter two of the Woodlots, belonging to my father’s Estate, excepting a small part of the line, which he this day finished. The survey of it by Mr Withington thus became unnecessary— The appraisers also went this day upon all the woodlots and I accompanied them— My brother’s two youngest Sons, John Quincy and Joseph Harrod, Farrar, and William Pote formed our party. My brother found himself so stiffened by the labour of the last, two days that he did not go. The weather was unpromising when we started; about 9. O’Clock. and it came on to rain just as we entered the woods for about two hours. It afterwards held up, and for the remainder of the day was cool and cloudy. The Sun shortly before setting came out clear— While the rain continued our work was uncomfortable— The rest of the day less Laborious than the two preceding— We dined at the same spot we had chosen the day before yesterday, and as we came out by the Railway and Bunker-Hill Ledges, we saw the workmen letting down two Monument Stones, weighing each upwards of two Tons— I continued my search for leaves and plants, attending more particularly this day to the Maples— The practice of cutting off the wood from these forests every fifteen or twenty years has so stunted them, that covered as they are with a beautiful growth of Oaks, it was with much difficulty that I obtained half a dozen twigs of black and white Oaks with young Acorns upon them—

p.unclear: I gathered a few Poke berries of the juice of which here is a specimen— Dr. Bigelow’s American Botany, Vol. 1. p. 39. calls this Phytolacca Decandra—and besides the name of Poke says it is in New-England more frequently called Garget, Cocum-Jalep, and Pigeon Berries— But he says this bright purple will in a very short time disappear.

div.p: I gathered also a few seeds of the Sugar maple— We saw one black Oak shrub nearly stripped of its leaves by a multitude of dark coloured worms about an inch long, of which without intending it, we brought a half a dozen home, upon a twig from another tree. I placed three of them under one of my glasses, to observe so long as I may have time their habits and if possible their changes. We found by information from Deacon Adams that Harmon the day before yesterday made another mistake in the lines and included a lot belonging to his brother Thomas in Mr Withington’s Survey. Farrar is to go to morrow Morning and give Mr Withington notice of this— After we returned home, I gave Mr Greenleaf, Mr Withington’s plots already completed. They are to view the Salt-marsh to morrow. Mrs Adams went into Boston this morning, to pass several days there. My Son John and Thomas B. Hellen, went with her.
2. V:15. Fair— Cloud. Rain. Clear.— Bath.

The appraisers of my father’s Estate, this day finished their view of the landed property— They first went down upon the Salt Marshes which occupied them until dinner time— After which they closed with the farm, round the house— I did not accompany them: being already acquainted with the places they have visited— My Son John returned this morning from Boston, and between twelve and one O’Clock we bathed at the wharf. I swam about half an hour— My brother’s youngest Son, Joseph H. came down and bathed while we were there— He has learnt to swim perfectly, and now only needs practice— I went and dined with General H. A. S. Dearborn at Brinley Place in On the way, I stopped at the Railway tavern, and saw the notice posted up in the bar room, signed by myself and Mr Quincy of our appointment as Executors of my father’s Will— It was already partly detached from the side of the Bar-room, and I reposted it myself— At General Dearborn’s the company consisted of J. W. Taylor, Speaker of the House of Representatives, U.S— Sir Isaac Coffin, D. Webster, E. Everett, J. Bailey, Messrs.Melville and Tracy of the Custom-House in Boston, Harris the Marshal, S. M. White and Colman of Salem, Austin, Gerry, S. A. Welles, Mr Pearce, Minister of Brookline, Dr. Hill Postmaster at Boston, and perhaps two or three more: Mrs Dearborn was the only Lady at table— Mr Pearce spoke to me of the remains of my father’s maternal family at Brookline— Boylston’s, and White’s, and of the antient family Estate in that Town, which has gone into other hands— Sir Isaac Coffin is an Admiral in The British Service; but a native of Boston, for which place he retains strong attachments. He spoke of his having once been upon a whaling voyage from Liverpool— Mr Taylor spoke to me after dinner upon Politics, and the electioneering fermentation in the State of New-York. He speaks with much bitterness of Mr Clinton, who he thinks is intriguing to supplant the Administration, and who he says has taken unwearied pains to get up an opposition to his, Taylor’s re-election in his district Taylor is however sangwine of his own re-election, and inclines to the opinion, that Clinton will supplant no one unless it should be himself. New-York is however utterly uncertain, and my only course is to prepare for retirement, as I hope I am now doing— It was about 9 in the Evening which I reached home, and I found my wife had returned from Boston, with Thomas J. Hellen—
3. IV:30. Heavy Thunder Shower:— Sultry Heat.

Heard Mr White of Dedham this morning from 2. Peter 1.4. “Whereby are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises; that by these ye might be partakers of the divine Nature.”— and in the afternoon from John 18.38. “What is truth”? Mr White is sensible and rational—preaches good morals, without vehemence or movement of Passions— He dined with us— Mr Winthrop and Mr Pringle came while we were at dinner— Coll. Davis and his brother just as the afternoon Bell rang. Davis came to ask me from General Wingate of Portland, Maine, if I would attend the Commencement at Bowdoin College and Lodge at his house in Portland. I had received a Letter from him with the same invitation, which I must decline— Van Rensselaer, the eldest Son of the Patroon, by his present wife, and Blunt are here upon a visit from New-York. Parkman, and his wife, with his Son by a former wife, called, on their return to Boston from a visit of a week to Hingham— Mr and Mrs D. Greenleaf paid an Evening visit— Meeting Mr Thomas Greenleaf after this Morning’s service, I spoke to him about the building of the Temple, to cover part of the expence of which, my father made a donation to the Town— They have made no advances to it since the Meeting of the Trustees immediately after my arrival here— I told him I would write a Letter to the Trustees of the Donation, stating to them my wishes with regard to the erection of the Temple, and that a vault might be constructed in which the remains of my father and mother may be entombed, and a marble tablet with a monumental inscription, upon one side of the Wall of the edifice— I also told him that I should be glad to have some written agreement with the Trustees or with the Inhabitants of the Town, upon the subject. He said if I would write, there might be called a meeting of the Inhabitants of the Town, who he believed would be willing to begin the building of the Temple very shortly. I owe it to the memory of my father and mother not to forget or neglect this affair, and I pray that I may have perseverance and a Spirit of devotion to it, that it may be accomplished before I myself go hence to be here no more. And should Providence in wisdom have decreed otherwise, I leave it in charge to my children, and exhort them to untiring Industry, and inflexible frugality that instead of squandering their means in extravagance and idleness, they may have to spare from their wants a tribute of reverence to their forefathers.
4. V.— Cloud. Rain— Cloud.— Bath.

Deacon Spear came and paid me as Executor of my father’s Will the proceeds of the Sales of grass standing on the Salt-marshes— Mr Cramer is the Son of Benedict Cramer of St. Petersburg— I saw him last year at Boston— Since which he has been to the Island of Cuba, and thence to New-Orleans and through the Western States. At one, I bathed at the wharf, with T. J. Hellen and my Son John— They went this afternoon to Cambridge— T. J. Hellen, has requested me to be his Guardian; Mr Thomas Cook of Georgetown, who was performing that Office, being now dead. He said his brother Johnson would perform all the troublesome part of the duty, but did not wish to exercise the authority, better suited to a person more advanced in years; and I have consented. Thomas had some thoughts also of quitting Cambridge for the present Sophomore year pursuing his studies at Exeter or elsewhere, and of returning for the succeeding years to the University— I left him entirely to his own option, and he finally concluded to return to Cambridge— John came back this Evening with Harriet Welsh— The remaining plans of the Surveys of my father’s real Estate were sent to me by Mr Withington and Asa French: and this afternoon I found in looking over my Grandfather John Adams’s Will that there were two lots of Woodland, given by it to my father, one of six and one of four Acres, not included in any of the Deeds— I supposed this might explain the difficulties we had met with last week, with regard to the boundaries— I took the copy of my Grandfather’s Will, to the Appraisers, who were assembled at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s; and found by the plans of Surveys, that the lots had been taken; but that there appeared still to be an error in the Survey of one of the lots, and a deficiency of at least five Acres of land— I determined to make further enquiries; but as the inventory must be returned to the Court of Probate to-morrow, the Appraisers made up their Report, upon the property as yet discovered, and to make a Supplementary Report, should any thing further be found.— Mr Daniel Greenleaf, brought me this Evening the Inventory, signed by the three Appraisers— The whole Estate, real, personal, and mixed amounts to a trifle more than forty-three thousand dollars— I was very much perplexed, and wasted not a little time, this day by the loss of the minutes I had made of all the Deeds of Real Estate left by my father— A work which must in substance be done over again— symbols 5 symbols
5. V. Heavy Rain. Variable. Bath. Dedham. Probate Court.

Morning visits— Dr Hill renewed his invitation to dinner, and I agreed to dine with him the 21st.— my brother and my Son John bathed with me at the wharf— Tide high— I swam only from wharf to wharf. Immediately after dinner I went with my brother to Dedham and attended the probate Court— I returned to the judge his order for giving notice of the appointing of the Executors, by posting and by publication in the Boston Independent Chronicle and Centinel Newspapers, and made Oath that it had been duly executed— I also returned the Inventory and Appraisement, signed by the three Appraisers; and before being sworn to the return, delivered to the judge a list of the Articles of wearing apparel, in use of my father to the time of his decease, which I told him had not been shewn to the Appraisers, there being a repugnance in the family that they should be exposed to sale, and it being supposed not customary to include such Articles in the Inventory. He said it would be sufficient to annex the list to the Inventory, and certify at the foot that those Articles were divided among the heirs; which I did— They consisted of old Clothing which I propose, giving to my brother, for him and his family: of a large Cornaline Seal of the Boylston Arms, slightly varied by him, which I have given to my brother; of a pair of gold Sleeve-buttons, which I have given to his Son, Thomas B. and a gold Stock buckle, which I propose to take myself, giving an equivalent for it to John A. Smith— The Cornaline Seal, with the Fishery Device he had directed Louisa C. Smith to give me, and his Silver Seal with his Cypher he had given to my Son John— I mentioned also to the judge the small tract of Land in Vermont, which he said need not be put into the inventory, but which he thought we might sell without the formality of taking out an Administration— I asked him if he had thought of the questions I had proposed to him respecting the conditional devises to me— He said he had no doubt my title would be valid; and he had consulted some of his legal friends who concurred in the opinion— I asked him whether the growing crop would be mine, or go to the Executors—he said it would be mine, as the Will required me to pay interest on the purchase from the time of the testator’s decease— I asked Mr Haven the Register for a copy of the Inventory, which he promised to furnish me— In about half an hour, I was dismissed— The Office was full of persons there on business. On returning to Gay’s Tavern, I saw judge Ware and Mr Loud, and returned with my brother to Quincy about Sunset.
6. V.— Variable. Bath alone. Weymouth

My brother went to Boston this Morning, and returned this Evening— My wife also went in, with Harriet Welsh and Louisa C. Smith; and my son John— Advertisements were prepared for publication, for the Sale of the Stocks, belonging to my father’s Estate, and of the Lands— I gave directions for the making of several rings, and other trinkets, with my father’s and mothers hair to make presents of to sundry persons— I gave these in charge to John— Wrote two short Letters: and at the high tide from one to two, I bathed alone, and swam from wharf to wharf. I remembered very imperfectly my Mother’s birth day, and being desirous of ascertaining it, I rode this afternoon, by the old Penn’s Hill Road to Weymouth, to the House of Mr Nathaniel Blancherd, Town-Clerk. He was not at home, but I found the old Town-Records which were shewn me by his wife. My Mother’s Birth day is there entered 11. Novr. 1744—old Style of course. This makes it 22. November New Style, which in the Episcopal Calendar’s is Saint Cecilia’s day. I asked Mrs Blancherd, if she had known my Grandfather Smith who was the Minister of Weymouth— She said no— She was only 44 years old; and as he died in 1783. She was then not more than a year old— I found also Entries of the publishment of my father and mother, 25. February 1764. and of their Marriage, by my Grandfather Smith 25. October 1764— The entries of the Birth marriage and death of several other persons of our family are also there— I then called and paid a visit to Mrs Tufts— Her daughter Susan, with Caroline Whitney had called this Morning to visit my wife— I returned from Weymouth over the Turnpike road; which having been opened within the last twenty years has none of those affecting associations of half a century’s memory, which every rock, and every tree upon the old Road carries with it— Some of those Recollections are very indistinct, and I was this Evening attempting to furbish them up by questions of Miss Sampson, but without much success— On returning home I found my Son John, who had come out from Boston, with Mr Lawrence of New-York: but they had come out only on a visit to the Ladies and immediately returned to Boston— My brother brought with him from Boston, a small Quarto volume, containing three very scarce early historical Books relating to New-England, Morton’s New English Canaan 1637—Wood’s New England’s Prospect, 1639. And Wonder-working Providence—A History of New-England, from 1628 to 1652 Printed in 1654. This book which has long been missing, was found at Mr James H. Foster’s, with some others left there by W. S. Shaw, and have remained there since his decease— I bought the book at an Auction in Berlin.
7. IV:30. Walk a mile— Ride to Braintree.

Dr Holbrook in conformity with my request, brought his Bill against my father’s Estate— Mr C. J. Adams of Dorchester brought me the family Chart of which his father was the author amended by the addition of a line of Samuel Adams one of the Sons of the first Henry, who settled in Chelmsford, and of whom Elijah when he made his Chart had no Account. Nathanael Beale is a brother of the late Captain Benjamin Beale, and resides in Boston. I had not seen him for many years— From Noon till half past two O’Clock I rode with my brother Stopped first at Mr Jedidiah Adams’s to ask him again for the loan of the first Henry Adams’s Will— But he said it had never been returned to him. So that I must look for it among my father’s papers— We thence went and called upon Deacon Daniel Spear, whom I informed of the Executor’s Advertisement of the intended Sale of my father’s Lands, and of the Household furniture and farming Stock, of which he is to be the auctioneer— I also accepted an offer which he had made me of six dollars for the Salt Hay standing on the Rock Island lot, which he paid me— One of my objects in calling upon him was to see his wife, whom I knew when we were both children, and whom I have scarcely seen to speak to since— Her name was Polly Belcher, daughter of Moses Belcher, a man who often worked upon my fathers farm, and who lived in a house directly opposite to that in which I was born— She is one year older than I am, and is a very respectable woman— She lives in a part of the town, where I know not whether I have been this half century; which was then almost a desolation, but is now thrifty and flourishing. It comes out much to my surprize, upon the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike, at the first Bridge— We proceeded thence through a Lane upon which was once a Cottage where Isaac Copeland lived, and where I once in boyhood spent a Sunday. The House is gone, but I found the spot where it had been— In these rambles, I am continually reminded of the line “and loves his old cotemporary trees,” the force of which I feel the older I grow. We went to the house of Mr Asa French, now the Town Clerk of Braintree; and I borrowed of him, the old Town-Records, which had been lent, three years since to my father by the then Town Clerk Wales, since dead— My father then had a copy of them made, which is however very imperfect, having been made by several hands— But the original is now in a much more mutilated condition than it was then— And it will probably soon be destroyed— Mr French lent it to me, and I spent much of the afternoon in comparing it with the copy— But these enquiries encroach too much upon my time— I asked Mr Brooks if the Hingham Church Records furnished the dates of the birth and marriage of Elizabeth Norton, wife of Coll. John Quincy; but he did not know— My Son John came out this Morning from Boston on the Carriage, and returned again this afternoon. George got home last Evening— Sick with an Ague.

Rose and lighted my lamp, the first time this Season— I wrote a Letter to the Supervisors, of the Temple & School fund, established in Town, by my father, expressing to them my wishes with regard to the erection of a modest monument to his Memory— I requested them to take the Sense of the Town, and of the Parish upon the building of the Temple, and upon my request that a vault or Tomb, may be constructed under it, in which the remains of my father and mother may be deposited with a Tablet or Tablets and obituary Inscriptions within the Walls— Mr Reynolds is an Inhabitant of Bristol Rhode-Island—and applies for the appointment of Surveyor of that Port vacated, by the Death of the late incumbent. He brought several Letters of recommendation, which I enclosed to the Secretary of the Treasury, with a proposal that a temporary Commission should be issued to Reynolds— I spoke to Mr Whitney upon the subject of building the Temple; and he mentioned again the expediency of having in it an Apartment, to receive the Library, given by my father to the Town—which I approved— I informed Mr Whitney also of my wish to join in Communion with the Church of which he is the Pastor— I ought to have joined it thirty years ago and more; but the tumult of the world, false shame, a distrust of my own worthiness to partake of the communion, and a residence elsewhere and continually changing made me defer it to a more convenient opportunity— But my fathers for nearly two Centuries have been members of this Church— My purpose is if my life should be spared till the end of my term of Public Service, to return and be gathered to my fathers here. It is right that I should make a public profession of my faith and hope as a Christian; and no time can be better for it than now immediately after the Death of my father and before my retirement from the public service, and the worldly cares of life. Mr Whitney told me the next Communion day would be the first Sunday, which is the first day of next Month— That it was usual for the Minister to announce the intention of the communicant on the preceding Sunday, and that before administering the first communion he called upon the communicant, for a profession of faith in Christianity very short, and in general terms— He did this conforming to antient usage, but he had exceedingly abridged the profession of faith, from that used formerly by his Predecessor Mr Wibird; and his own inclination was that it should hereafter be omitted altogether. The persons whose names are in the Margin were visitors before and after dinner— Mr Marston dined and spent the remainder of the day with us. Mr Burse is a Stranger— A drover who has come from the State of Maine Gloucester, 24. Miles from Portland with a herd of Cattle for Sale at Bridgewater— He came merely from curiosity to see the President of the United States and said he had once voted for me, to be Governor of the State— I was confined to the House, by Company and the weather all day after the Morning. John came out from Boston late this Evening.
9. V:15. Boston— Dined at Jos. Hall’s— Quincy.

Adam Hardwick came early this Morning, to enquire about taking this place, which he is desirous of taking as they call it by the halves— I told him I did not know exactly what the place would be, as all the woodlands and all the Saltmarsh belonging to it were to be sold: I should perhaps purchase part of both; and if I should, the woodland would be left untouched, but the Saltmarsh would give additional value to the farm— I said I would see him again after the Sales— I received a Letter from De Witt Clinton, Governor of New-York with enclosures complaining of an Advertisement in the National Intelligencer, for the Sale of a coloured Man, whom they claim as a Free man, and a Citizen of New-York. I enclosed all the papers to Mr Clay at Washington, with a request that he would act upon them, as the laws would warrant— John returned to Boston, on Horse back, and I went with William in the chaise. I stopped at Mr Stuart the Painter’s, and there saw the Portrait of my wife for the first time— It is unfinished, and he promised to finish it, but asked that she would give him another sitting— I then went to Hamilton’s Hotel, where I found her, and Thomas J. Hellen with her— Then I called at Dr Welsh’s, and saw my Son George, who has been exceedingly ill, during his late excursion; first at New-York; then at Lebanon Springs to which he returned; and finally with a severe tooth-ache and swollen face, with which he came back on Wednesday Evening extremely ill— He is now apparently recovering which relieves me from the deepest anxiety. I saw also the Doctor, John and Harriet Welsh— Then went and dined at Mr Joseph Hall’s, where I met Mr and Mrs Everett, Mr and Mrs Palfrey Hall’s sister Son and daughter— Made some enquiries concerning the value of the Middlesex Canal Stock— On returning to the Hotel, I found there a Mr Edward Byrne, formerly an Inspector of the Customs at New-York, who wishes to be reinstated in the Office— He brought me Letters of Recommendation from Governor Clinton, and from the Mayor of New-York, and others— The appointments are made by the Collector, sometimes with Recommendations from the Secretary of the Treasury, to whom I advised Mr Byrne to direct his application, and to whom I told him I would write concerning him. Mr Catlett of Alexandria, also called upon me— I came out in the Chaise again with William to Quincy; Mrs Adams, and John remaining in Boston, to be with George— On returning home I found a very large package from Mr Felt, W. S. Shaw’s Administrator, enclosing a multitude of manuscript Books and papers belonging to my father and to me, and which he has found among Shaw’s papers upon examination at the request of my brother.
10. V:30. Showery.

Frequent Showers all the morning, and afternoon. cleared off towards Sunset— On going into my father’s pew, I found Mr Isaac Smith there— Mr Whitney preached from Romans 13.10. “Love worketh no ill to his neighbour: therefore love is the fulfilling of the law.” Mr Smith dined with us, and preached this afternoon from James 5.7.8. “Be patient therefore, brethren, unto the coming of the Lord. Behold the husbandman waiteth for the precious fruit of the earth, and hath long patience for it, until he received the early and latter rain.— Be ye also patient; stablish your hearts: for the coming of the Lord draweth nigh.”— Mr Smith came again, and will pass the Night here. He is the only surviving Son of my grandfather Smith’s brother Isaac—was graduated at Harvard College in 1767, and must now be in his 78th. year— He resided in England during the whole of our revolutionary War, but returned here immediately after the Peace, and has lived a bachelor to this age— I asked him some questions concerning his family— He told me his father had one brother, named Thomas, besides my Grandfather, and several Sisters, one of whom married Dr Tufts’sfather, oneSamuel Edwards, one an Austin and one a Kent. He named to me numerous families with whom their descendents have become connected; most of which are unknown to me. I told him that on seeing him in the pulpit this afternoon, I had been much struck with the remembrance that I had heard him preach on the same spot upwards of fifty years ago. It was just before he went to England, but he had no recollection of it. Upon examining this morning the papers sent by Mr Felt, I found many of my own writing, which I had utterly forgotten; and a very few, of which even after recognizing them as my own hand-writing I could not remember.— Messrs.Greenleaf, Miller and Beale were this Evening at my brother’s Office, with him as Supervisors of the Temple and School fund given by my father to the Town. There will be a Parish Meeting in October, and a Town Meeting in November when the Sense of these bodies will be taken upon my proposals respecting the monument to my father and mother— They offered to call Meetings earlier if I should desire it, but as nothing effective can be done before my return to Washington, and as Individuals would be put to inconvenience by calling extraordinary Meetings, I agreed to leave the Subject to be decided at the regular Meetings— There are questions relating to property in this case, which require much consideration— I found and read to these Gentlemen some minutes in my father’s Journals of Novr. 1760. concerning this very question. I advised them to apply to the Legislature for an Act to incorporate them as Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School fund at Quincy, to which there appeared to be no objection on their part— Something was said of drafting a Petition for an Act of Incorporation, and a Bill, which deserves attention. My Son John came out this afternoon from Boston, and returned there again—
11. V:30.— Mount Wollaston Farm.

Mr Smith left us this morning after Breakfast— He told me he had heard that he was born in 1749. Mrs Eustis called to pay a visit to my wife, supposing her to be here— Mr Browne is a composer of Music, and a Teacher, upon a new system invented by a man named Logier, who has a Patent for an instrument called a Chiroplast, for the use of which Browne gave him a hundred guineas— Browne is an Irishman recently arrived in this Country, with a family, and has a few pupils in Boston. But he has some difficulty, in importing Pianos for his School, and he asked my permission to publish a march which he has composed for the 4th. of July, and to which he gives my name. Mr B. F. Hunt was introduced to me, by T. Greenleaf— Hunt is a native of this Region, the vicinity of Boston— Has been settled since the year 1810. at Charleston, South Carolina, has been a member of the Legislature of that State, and is a very active politician— He cautioned me to beware of Cleary the Sheriff who has written me several Letters; to all which I have returned one short answer— He said there was no reliance to be placed upon Cleary, who was honest in his intentions; sincere in the expression of his feelings; but flighty and changeable— Mr Hunt’s friends are Mr Bennett and judge Gaillard— He advises against removals from Office, and wishes something may be done to conciliate the Southern Planters with regard to the security of their Negro-property— Mr and Mrs Foster came out from Boston immediately after dinner— I had engaged to go with my brother to my Mount Wollaston farm— The Tenant of the house Alpheus Spear, shewed us all the Salt-marshes which are in great need of ditching, and some dilapidations in the house which require repairs: all which he wishes to have done by my authority and at my charge— He also shewed me a spot where he thought Squire Bass had encroached upon my marsh, which I think highly probable. Spear’s wife is a daughter of Micajah Adams, and lived once in my family— They have four small children— After our return, Mr Foster spoke to me of my father’s bequest to Louisa C. Smith, which he said she wished I would give security to her for, upon interest, like that which I have already of hers in my hands— To which I agreed. I asked Mr Foster to bid for me next week at the sale of the Stocks, which he promised. Mrs Clarke and Elizabeth C. Adams went to Boston, and returned this Evening. They received information of the Death of Mr Charles Harrod’swife in Louisiana. My Son John came out from Boston this Evening. His mother remains there to attend upon George, who has again been this day taken very ill— I received the Treaty with Mexico—and a Letter from J. Scott of Missouri.
12. V.30.— Variable— Hingham— Quincy.

Mr Smith called here again this Morning, and spent an hour, having missed of the morning Stage to return to Boston— General Dearborn called for a visit, having recently returned from the State of Maine. Mr Quincy was also here having been upon a like excursion to the extremity of that State— His health is improved. I told him all that had hitherto been done by me, towards the Execution of the Will of my Father, to all which he assented. He said he would speak to the proprietors of the Railway, or some of them respecting the sale of the Lots of Land, through which they have passed— I also mentioned to him the disposal made of the wearing apparel, and the suggestion made by the judge of Probate, that it would be proper he Quincy should also sign the paper relating to the distribution of it; which he said he would— After dinner I rode with my brother to Hingham— We travelled by the old road, with which I was familiar when a child, but over which, from Weymouth I have not passed perhaps these forty years— We visited first, Quincy Thaxter and his three daughters Susanna, and Anna; and in the same house the aged maiden Celia— The other Sister, Elizabeth who was living when I last came with my father in September 1823; soon after died— We called next at Mr Brooks the Ministers but he was not at home. We then went to Mr Thomas Thaxter’s and Edward Thaxter’s, his Son, and there saw the two Ladies, Mother and daughter— After which we called at Mr Loring’s where we saw Mr and Mrs Loring, their Son, and their daughter with her husband Captain Whittemore— The Thaxter’s are all descendents from Coll. John Thaxter who married Anna Quincy, second daughter of my great-Grandfather John Quincy— I frequented the house much in my infancy, and was always treated with great kindness in it— At Mr Loring’s we met Mr Brooks— We returned by the new roads over the Turnpikes and Bridges; newer and better Roads, but with other and far less interesting associated recollections. On reaching home I was relieved from much anxiety, by finding my wife and both my Sons there. George much better than I had expected. They came out from Boston this afternoon— John had gone in this morning— Mr Edward Miller came in upon a visit; introducing Dr Thacher of Plymouth; who is preparing for publication a biographical account of all the eminent physicians of North America— Afterwards there came Isaac Bassett of the Society of Friends, who informed me that Elizabeth Robson, whom I heard preach last Winter, at Washington, was here and very desirous of calling upon me, for which I appointed to-morrow Morning between 8 and 9. O’Clock. I received a Letter from W. N. Boylston, with copies of Mr Clarke’s Sermon.

Deacon Spear came this morning to make enquiries concerning the Sales, of the Lands of my father’s Estate, and of the household furniture in this house. The Sale of the Stocks is advertised to be in Boston next Monday— And that of the Lands at French’s Tavern in Quincy next Tuesday. Advertisements of the latter Sale were now prepared to be posted up in this Town; and also an Advertisement for the Sale of the Household furniture the Stock on the farm, the two Pews in the Meeting House, and the Tomb, which I determined should be on the 27th. and 28th of this Month— Deacon Spear said it would be necessary there should be a Clerk with him to keep an account of the Sales, and make out the Bills, and named Captain Bracket, or John Whitney— I told him I would give him an answer upon this in a few days— Elizabeth Robson the female Quaker preacher, with two other women and two men, came upon their Morning visit— Wistar and one of the women are from Philadelphia— The other woman came from England with Elizabeth, and Bassett is of Lynn. They are returning from a tour to Nantucket, and Elizabeth is now going to Montreal and Quebec. After the usual Salutations, Elizabeth sat some time with her hand covering her face as in deep meditation, and then addressed me in a formal religious exhortation of about a quarter of an hour concerning the cares and duties of the Ruler of a Nation, but particularly upon the condition of the poor, oppressed coloured people in this Country. after finishing her Address, and a short pause, she rose from the Sofa, turned and kneeled before it, and made a short prayer to God in my behalf— A short time after she had finished, the woman from Philadelphia made also a formal brief address; but in general terms and without reference to the Slaves— My wife and my brother with his family were present. We heard them with respectful attention, and when they rose to withdraw, I thanked them for their exhortations and their prayers—observing that in the public trust with which I am charged, I had great need of the prayers of all worthy persons; and as to what Elizabeth had said concerning the condition of the poor coloured people in this Country, I should lay it seriously to heart and should act with a view to promote the glory of God, and the best interests of this great people. They then took leave— General Miller came to solicit a Midshipman’s warrant for his Son, and Edmund Burke for an appointment as Light-House keeper at Warwick Neck, Rhode Island, with Recommendations— My wife and George went this afternoon to Nantasket Beach to stay till Friday; and I paid Evening visits to the widow Miller and to Edward Miller— I made this day a draft of an Act of incorporation of the Supervisors of the Temple and School Fund.
14. V: Bath. Swam half an hour. Boston— Gerry’s— Quincy

Mr Marston came with Coll. Throop of Bristol who solicited the appointment of Surveyor of that Port— He was recommended by Mr Marston’s Son in Law D’Wolfe— I told Throop that I had already directed the temporary appointment of Mr Reynolds; who he said was his neighbour, and well qualified for the Office— Mr Quincy was here and had further conversation with me, concerning the Execution of my father’s Will— I spoke of presenting a suit of Clothes to Mr Whitney, who officiated at the funeral, which he approved, but suggested some objections to the printing of the Sermon— He spoke also of the woodland through which the Railway passes, and he promised to see T. H. Perkins to ascertain whether the Proprietors propose to purchase the land; and if so, what they are willing to give for it— I told him that I wished to own the land; as it was part of my fathers Estate, and should bid for it beyond the appraisement; but I could not bid at the rate at which they had purchased the neighbouring Lands. I said as the Railway itself was a project which if successful would be very advantageous to both the Towns of Quincy and of Boston, I wished to give it every encouragement in my power— If the Railway Company did not want the Lands, I should purchase them— If they did, I should be willing to make an arrangement with them, and become myself a Proprietor with them— That he might say all this to Perkins, and add that I would deal in perfect Candour with the Company asking them to do the same with me— I bathed after Breakfast between 9 and 10. Joseph Bartlett was here; a monumental ruin. He said he had walked out from Boston, and had lived upon milk since last April. Dr Waterhouse came also to spend the day here, but I was obliged to go in to Boston— He remained here to dine, and promised to come again, Saturday the 24th.— I went with John to Boston, and stopped at the Exchange Hotel— Called before dinner at Mr Cruft’s and afterwards at judge Joseph Hall’s— I dined at Elbridge Gerry’s: with the Lieutt. Governor Winthrop, the two Generals Dearborn—E. Everett, G. BlakeJ. T. Austin, N. Silsbee, Dr. Warren, and two or three others— Mrs. Gerry the mother, a young Lady and James Gerry were also there— The old Lady having entirely recovered her health— I promised Lieutt Governor Winthrop to dine with him on the 27th— After dinner I returned to the Exchange Hotel, and thence with John to Quincy— Just after we got back commenced a long and heavy Shower Going to the City this morning, we overtook Mr Quincy on horseback; also going in. He had not seen Perkins, but said he had been bargaining for me, all the morning; and that he would call upon me at the Hotel, before dinner, but he did not.
15. V. Fair— Cool. Dorchester— Quincy.

My Son John was seized in the Night with violent cramps in the Stomach, and he thinks Cholera Morbus. He called up, my brother’swife, who with others of the family attended him till near the dawn of day. Mrs Adams administered to him an emetic of Ipecac and flower of Antimony which gave him relief—and this morning he took a dose of Castor Oil— I knew nothing of his illness till this morning, when I found him in bed with a deeply flushed face, in a strong perspiration, and some fever. He kept house and fasted the whole day, but had no return of his illness, and towards Evening was sufficiently recovered to do business— Mr Benjamin Clark Cutler, Minister of the Episcopal Church in this Town, came with a solicitation in behalf of some person, for an appointment as Consul at some Port in South-America. I told him I knew of only one vacancy there; which was at Santa Martha, the Consul at which place Fudger was recently murdered at Bogota— And I advised that his friend should make his application to the Secretary of State, and forward with it such respectable recommendations of his character as he could obtain— Mr George Smith is a brother of Mrs Charles Miller, now boarding at Dorchester, and wishing also to obtain a place of Inspector at the Custom-House in Boston— I wrote Letters this morning to R. Rush and to my Son Charles and after dinner rode to Dorchester, where I paid visits— First to Dr Codman the Minister, who resides in an elegant house, with the most beautiful of Prospects on Spurr’s hill— There were at his house besides his wifehis mother in Law, the widow Codman, once the gay and brilliant Catherine Amory, an Aunt Codman, Sister to his father—the widow of John M’Lean, Sister to old Mrs Codman, and his brother Charles Codman, with his handsome wife, and an infant who had come out this afternoon on a visit from Boston— I next went to Mr T. K. Jones’s, but found that he and his family had removed some weeks into Boston. My third call was on my Classmate, Dr Thaddeus Mason Harris, Minister of the first Church in Dorchester, with whom I compared some old recollections of forty years, when we were fellow Students at Cambridge. Mrs Harris came home from a visit to Mrs Nicholson, at Mr Edward Miller’s in Quincy while I was there— I came home by the old lower road from Milton to Boston, over which I had not passed for I think more than twenty years— I found few alterations in it. The evening was fine, cool, and entirely autumnal— I began to draft papers for the Settlement of my father’s Estate in execution of his Will— In reflecting upon the subject, I find it not without embarrassments. In conversing this day with my brother upon his purposes I find them more unsettled than they were a Month back.
16. V.— Clear— Cold— Dorchester. Withington’s— Quincy.

Mr Curtis and Mr Haven came from Boston, with a Letter from the Agent of Lloyd’s at Sydney, in the Island of Cape Breton, announcing the arrival there of four men, from the Schooner Fairy of Boston which vessel they had scuttled, and murdered her Captain and Mate. The men have been taken up and imprisoned at Sydney, and these persons are desirous that application should be made to the British Government on the Island, to deliver them up to be tried here at Boston— The vessel belonged to A. and C. Cunningham, and the Captain was a son of the late T. O. Selfridge. I advised Mr Curtis to address his application to the Secretary of State, with documents such as he might possess to substantiate the facts— I said I would also write to him, advising the application, and it might be made through the British Minister at Washington— I doubted however whether the men would be delivered up; the British Government not being in that practice, and we having on similar occasions declined delivering up men at their request to them. But if they should refuse to deliver them, it will become their duty to try them, which we shall request as an alternative— Mr Davis afterwards called, and spoke of this atrocious crime with much feeling, the chief criminal in this horrid act, having been but last year a Seaman in a vessel of which his second Son was Captain and having proved extremely troublesome to him— I went this afternoon to see Mr Withington the Surveyor at Dorchester— He was engaged upon some business at the Hill of Dr Harris’s Meeting House, where I found him— He soon returned to his house, where I examined with him his Surveys of the Woodlands belonging to my father’s Estate, comparing them with the Deeds and with some antient surveys which I found among the papers. The Deeds together with the two lots given by my Grandfather’s Will to my father shew 131 Acres of Woodland; while Withingtons Surveys, make only 109. There must be then at least 20 Acres not returned upon the Surveys— We made some progress in the attempt to ascertain where they are; and Withington promised to come to me, Monday morning to pursue the enquiry further— On coming home, I found my wife and my Son George returned from their excursion to Nantasket, George continuing so ill that immediately after they arrived Dr Holbrook was sent for and came in the Evening— His state of health gives me the deepest concern, and fears which I scarcely dare think of, and cannot contemplate with composure— My brother went this morning to Boston, and returned this Evening— He obtained at the Office of the Register of Deeds in Boston, the original boundaries of the Quincy lot. I drafted several papers for the Execution of my father’s Will.

Heard this Morning Mr Capen of Dorchester, from Matthew 7:20. “Wherefore by their fruits ye shall know them”— After dinner I rode up to Braintree to hear Mr Storrs, but was disappointed. He is absent, and a Stranger preached in his place from Matthew 25.30. “And cast ye the unprofitable servant into utter darkness: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth”— The Quincy Church is the first, and the Braintree Church the second, established in the old Town of Braintree; and the two texts of the two preachers at them this day, selected from the same Gospel of Matthew, contain a complete summary of the opposite Doctrines which prevail in them. Arminian Unitarianism at Quincy— Trinitarian Calvinism at Braintree— The delivery of both the preachers was temperate, or rather cold. Mr Capens Discourse was plain, rational, and argumentative against infidelity. The Calvinist threatened eternal reprobation in so mild and even sluggish a manner that no small portion of his auditory slumbered over the precipice. I walked home, the distance being about three Miles and a half— I stopped on my way at the house of Joseph Field, next door to that in which I was born— He told me that he was 77 years old, and that there was now only one man older than himself in Quincy—Joseph Baxter— But he said his eldest Sister; Susanna, who married Jonathan Baxter, and who as his mother told him, held me at the font, when I was baptized, was yet living, aged 83— I asked him many questions about his own family; his brothers, Sisters and Children, which he answered somewhat confusedly, and produced a book containing his own minutes of his own marriages and of the births marriages and deaths of his Children, and some few of his brothers and Sisters— It was a Tale of Crabbe’s, stripp’d of its poetry— On coming home I found my wife preparing to go in to Boston, and thence proceed on her return to Washington. Her health is very infirm, and I told my Son John to go with her. They left this House about five O’Clock— George continues exceedingly unwell— I spent the Evening with him in his chamber, and determined to share his bed— After the morning service Mr Quincy came home with me, and conversed with me upon the Execution of my father’s Will— I shewed him my drafts, which in substance he approved— He had not seen T. H. Perkins; but intended to return to Boston to see him this Evening. He had seen I. P. Davis, who told him he thought the Railway-Company would not bid for any of the Woodland, at the Sale of my father’s Lands. I gave him a gold ring, plain, with hair of my father’s enchased in it— I examined again the Deeds and Surveys of my father’s Estate. John’s going away and George’s illness have very much increased my difficulties and embarrassments— I look forward with trembling hope, and an aching heart. May I be sustained by that which can alone sustain.
18. V. Walk to E. Miller’s corner.

Mr Withington and Deacon Adams came this Morning, and we re-examined all the Deeds, Wills and Surveys to ascertain where the Lands not included in Withington’s Survey can be— We got however little information further than what I had traced on Saturday. Deacon Adams thought the Savil lot of eleven Acres had been occupied by my uncle Peter’s heirs, and said there had been some question between him and my father’s woodsmen, in their life time about the boundaries— I sent for Peter Turner, my uncle’s Administrator, and after some examination, we agreed that Withington should make a new survey the day after to-morrow, at which Turner should be present. Deacon Adams told me that several persons had spoken to him about purchasing some of the lots, and advised me, if I wished to purchase, not much to regard the appraisements as returned in the Inventory. He thought the whole Land would not sell for more than the appraisement; but particular Lots might be bidden for higher— I asked him to bid for me and he said he would come to-morrow Morning, and receive directions from me, as to the limits of his bidding— Mason came with an account against my fathers Estate which I paid— Mr Sampson and his daughter this morning, and Mr Flynt of Cohasset towards Evening called to pay visits— My Son John came out from Boston, and dined with us; and returned this Evening to Boston. He brought here the Jewelry I had ordered, and I gave George the ring intended for him— He also brought me a large budget of despatches and Letters, among which one from Mr Quincy who has seen T. H. Perkins, and thinks the Railway Corporation will purchase the Woodlots through which they pass at any price— This makes it necessary for me carefully to conciliate my duty to the Estate, to obtain the utmost for the Lands, with my duty to my own family not to involve myself with burdensome, and profitless purchases— My wife has postponed her intended departure for Washington— I slept with George last Night. He is this day rather better, but still exceedingly feeble— I had this Evening a long conversation with him, upon his own purposes and prospects for the future, and upon those of his brother John; subjects which occasion great concern to their mother and to me. His Explanation and Declarations were satisfactory to me, so far as he knows his own feelings; and for the rest we must hope and trust.

The Sale of the Lands, Salt-marsh and Wood land belonging to my father’s Estate was this day made by Deacon Spear at French’s tavern— The Deacon came here about seven this morning, and I arranged with him the conditions of the Sale, and gave him the plans taken by Mr Withington, to be exhibited at the Sale— Deacon Adams came soon after and took my directions for bidding on my Account— While he was with me I received a Letter from Mr Quincy, mentioning that he had again seen Coll. Perkins who told him, that the Directors of the Railway Company would be governed by circumstances— Quincy still inferred that they would have the land at any price, and cautioned me to beware of attempting to outbid them, beyond what I thought the land was worth. But I directed Deacon Adams, whatever price they should bid, to bid one dollar more for it— The Lands were all bidden off for me; all within the limits I had prescribed, and very near the apprized value; excepting the two Lots for which Coll. Perkins bid, for one nearly three times, and for the other more than four times the appraisement. The Sale began at eleven O’Clock, and was over in about an hour— Harriet Welsh came out with George, and returned to Boston with him in the Evening— I gave her as from my father a Locket with his hair in it— Mr Curtis came to make some enquiries, concerning an interest that he has in a Patent; for which I necessarily referred him to the Department of State and the Courts of Law. President Kirkland came and dined and spent the day with us— Mr brother went to attend the Court at Dedham, and returned in the Evening— A Captain Glover with his brother also a Captain, and a Mr Hillegas of Philadelphia stopped to deliver me a packet of Books, with a Letter from a Mr Shecut of Charleston S. Carolina— I took a short walk in the Evening; having been confined by business and company, all the rest of the day to the house. Found Mr G. W. Beale here upon my return. Had a long conversation afterwards with George— After the Sale this morning Deacon Spear came with Captain John Whitney, and made report of the Sales— They made also with my Son George preparation for the Sale of the Household furniture, and farming Stock, on the 27th.John brought me out a Letter from his mother, and I directed him to say to her that I wished her to go wherever she thought it would most conduce to her health and comfort; and if she would let me know any thing she wished me to do, I would do it.
20. V. Boston— Quincy.

Mr Withington and my brother with Peter Turner, Ordway and Farrar, went again this morning to resurvey the Woodland belonging to the Estate of my father which had been erroneously taken before. I could not go with them, being obliged to go into Boston, to execute the transfers of Stocks sold last Monday. I went in with William, and stopp’d first at Mr James H. Foster’s— Saw only Mrs Foster and her daughter Louisa— I examined all the books left by W. S. Shaw, but found among them, none of mine except those which had been discovered before— I thence went to the Exchange Hotel, where I found my wife and John— Nathl. Amory and Isaac P. Davis paid me a visit, and I engaged to dine with Amory at Watertown, next Saturday week the 30th.— Mr Quincy, my Co-Executor came, and Brown the Broker who sold the Stocks. He went and executed the transfers at the Fire and Marine, and New-England Insurance Offices, at the Massachusetts, Boston and American Banks— At the West-Boston Bridge and Boylston Market Offices— For the stocks transferred to me, as for the rest, I signed as joint-Executor the transfer, and then in my individual capacity for the Certificates of Stocks delivered to me: which were of the two Insurance Companies and of the West-Boston Bridge. The Middlesex Canal Shares are yet to be transferred— We agreed that Mr Browne should deposit the proceeds of the Sales to the credit of the Executors in the U.S. Branch Bank, and the Cashier of the Bank, agreed to make payments on the check of either of the Executors. I returned to Quincy to dinner. My brother returned from the woods, between 5 and 6 in the afternoon— They had found the bounds of the Beale and Quincy lots, and the true boundary mark, between Quincy and Milton; but the eleven Acre Savil lot remains yet to be found; and Mr Withington is to come again next Monday. Dr Holbrook was here this afternoon, and I enquired of him, what he thought of the state of my wife’s health— He said he believed there was disease in the right ovarium that it was irremediable and would occasionally be very troublesome; but he did not consider it as dangerous to life, and might continue through the ordinary term of life— It was the occasion of great nervous irritability, and excitement, but transient in its paroxisms— I took this opinion of him; because she herself thinks the disease mortal— I hope and trust the Doctor’s opinion is correct.
21. V. Roxbury— Cambridge, Boston. Quincy.

Peter Turner came this morning, and brought an old Deed from Samuel Bass to John Adams, my grandfather dated April 1717, of ten Acres of Land, but we could not ascertain where it was. I resolved to have further enquiries made at the Office of the Register of Deeds— I left with George who is this day much better, the two old Record Books of the Town of Braintree, to examine them for any thing relating to the Sale of town Lands. I went to Cambridge and dined at Dr. Aaron Hills. Met John before I reached Neponsit Bridge— He was coming out on horseback, and asked me to go through Boston, to see his mother who was ill with a severe attack of Dysentery; for which Dr Bigelow had been called in. As I wished to call on the two General’s Dearborn, father and Son, at Roxbury, I determined to return through Boston— Neither of the Generals was at home, but I saw Mrs Dearborn, and returned to her the manuscript epitome of entomology, which he had lent me two Months since— On reaching Cambridge I called at Dr Waterhouse’s and he shewed me two Letters from my father to him dated in August and September 1805 upon Sea-weed; which the Doctor proposed sending to the American Academy of arts and Sciences, and also to communicate to President Kirkland, who is to deliver an Eulogy, before the Academy in October— The Doctor shewed me also a Letter from myself to him written in 1813 and asked my leave to make what use of it he pleased, which I gave him— He went with me to President Kirkland’s, and we all went, and viewed, the Philosophy room, now where the chapel formerly was—the Cabinet of Mineralogy which was the Commons Hall— The Library, occupying the chamber where it formerly was and also the old philosophy chamber, and the anatomical and chemical lecturing rooms. President Kirkland dined with us at Dr Hill’s, whose four daughters were present— Mrs Hill absent from indisposition. The two Generals Dearborn, Mr Quincy, Messrs.Bailey, Everett, Fuller, Sprague and one or two more were there. I had met the Professors of the University, at President Kirkland’s, before dinner— I returned to Quincy in the Evening, stopping in Boston to see my wife, whom I found ill in bed, but much better than she had been— She conversed with me on family subjects of painful interest, till I was fearful she would be exhausted, and she requested me, to return to Quincy to attend to my necessary business, and to be with George. I accordingly came, and got home between 9 and 10 in the Evening. Found George gaining strength, but still affected with grave symptoms. I sat with him an hour, and then signed the daily packet of Land-grants.
22. V:15.— Boston. Quincy

Deacon Savil came this morning, and I had a long conversation with him concerning this farm, and how it may be best for me to dispose of it— Deacon Savil himself for the last five or six years has cultivated the farm for my father; to raise and get in the crops, but not to dispose of them— I had offered the management of the farm to my brother, who declined undertaking it— I now offered it to Deacon Savil who also declined. I then asked his advice and opinion, how it could be most advantageously disposed of to be kept two or three years till I may come and take the management of it upon myself. I finally requested him to make an estimate of what the place might probably be rented for, with, or without a Stock of Cattle, and holding the Tenant to terms which would keep the Land in a condition as good as it now is. I had also a Conversation with my Son George upon his prospects and future purposes in which I made known to him my own intentions with regard to my father’s Estate, and his grants to the Town for a Temple and School fund. I told him that after my discharge from the public service, the objects of my life for its short remainder would be to accomplish the two designs for which he made his grants to the Town of Quincy— The erection of a Temple built of Stone, and the Establishment of a School or Academy, for the preparatory Education of youth for the University—and with this to do as far as may be in my power justice to the memory of my father, by writing Memoirs of his Life— George is perfectly well disposed in his intentions; and if his health may be spared I indulge the hope that he may be a useful assistant to me and a successor to my endeavours for accomplishing the benevolent intentions of my father— I went to Boston about Noon; and called twice at Mr Stuart’s, the Painter’s— The second time I found him and he promised to make a copy of his last Portrait of my father, that I may have it to take with me to Washington. But he talks of going to New-Bedford next week, and to Washington next Winter— MessrsCallender and Apthorp paid me a visit at the Exchange Hotel, and Dr Bigelow called to visit my wife; who is yet confined to her bed, slowly convalescent. I dined at Dr. George Parkman’s with a mixed company—Dr. Gardner the episcopal Minister, Dr Ware the professor of Divinity at Cambridge—F. Parkman the Minister, Mr and Mrs R. G. Shaw— Messrs.Brimmer, L. N. Rogers of Baltimore, Dr. Gorham and several others were there. After dinner Dr Parkman walked with me to the Exchange Hotel, where I stopped again about half an hour— My wife was better, and had been up part of the afternoon. I left Harriet Welsh, and our son John with her; and returned to Quincy, with William— Got home about nine
23. IV:45.— Walk round the Lanes. 4 Miles.

Having risen before daylight I walked round by the meeting house and the old mill pond through the lane which comes into the old road opposite Arnold’s, and back by the old ninth Mile Stone, and Mr T. Greenleaf’s— I was an hour and eight minutes out, whence I conclude that the distance is four miles— I was nine minutes from the house to the tenth mile Stone; and eleven minutes from the ninth Mile Stone to the House— Coll. Perkins called upon me, and said he had been here, at Mr Jonathan Beale’s this whole week; in attendance upon the Rail-way; of which he is the first and greatest undertaker— It is now nearly completed and he expects will be in operation about the tenth of next Month— He has further and more extensive projects of Railways, from Boston to Hudson and Connecticut Rivers; but said it would require a reduction of the duty upon imported Iron— He spoke also of his having bidden for the Railway Corporation at the Sale last Monday upon two of the Woodlots, and I mentioned to him my motives for out bidding him, which I said I should have done, whatever his limits might have done— He said the Directors had limited him to 150 dollars an Acre, but they would probably have run it thirty or forty dollars higher, but for their willingness that I should have it. He invited me to visit the Railway again, before my return to Washington, which I assured him it was my intention to do— Dr Waterhouse and Mr Marston dined here— The Doctor shewed me several old Letters from my father to him, some of them very confidential. My Son John, and Thomas J. Hellen also came out from Boston to dine and returned in the Evening. John brought me out my Hickory Cane, which I took from one of the Woodlots while we were surveying, and upon a silver ring under the pommel of which is engraved “Walk humbly,” with the date of the year, and my initials J. Q. A— It is also a Yard Stick though not as I had directed from the ring to the ferule— I have procured it as a staff and Memorial for old age, of my late rambles over these Quincy Woodlands. This Evening I had another long conversation with my Son George in which he opened to me the state of his own mind, and feelings, with the most confidential sincerity— His heart is pure; but his imagination outruns his judgment, his ambition is ardent, and his temper tending too much to despondency; to which his present feeble state of health contributes. My prayer to God is that he may be spared and saved.

Heard Mr Whitney this morning, from Matthew 22.29. [“]Jesus answered and said unto them, ye do err, not knowing the scriptures”—a controversial unitarian discourse, consisting chiefly of expositions, of the texts of Scripture, cited by Trinitarians in defence of their creed.— Without positively declaring his disbelief in the existence of the devil—whom he considers as a mere personification of Sin— Mr Brooks of Hingham preached this afternoon, from Hebrews 12.2. “Looking unto Jesus”— This was altogether practical— Mr Brooks is intelligent, and writes well, but has a drawling manner of delivery. At the close of the Service he gave notice that the Communion would be administered the next Lord’s day, and of my desire, and that of Seaver and his wife, and of Hannah Lee to join in full communion with the Church— Mr Brooks accepted my invitation to take tea with us and his brother lately returned after an absence of five years in Europe came with him— Mr Quincy called here, and we had conversation concerning the Execution of my father’s Will— He approved of the draft, I had made for a Deed of the Lands sold, from the Executors to me— I had not yet finished any of the others— I spoke of the Sale of the Tomb, and of the Report that a thousand dollars would be offered for it upon a speculation. He expressed some regret that it had been included in the inventory and proposed that it should be made a condition of Sale that if it should be purchased by any person not of the family it should not be delivered to the purchaser in less than four years— But the Law and the Will imperatively require the Sale, and I thought it would be sufficient to give notice at the Sale, that if the Tomb should be purchased by any person not of the family, the Executors reserved to themselves the right of removing the coffins and persons deposited in them to another before they would deliver possession of the Tomb to the purchaser— I spoke also to Mr Quincy of my father’s donations to the Town for the erection of a Temple, and a School, and of my own wishes before the close of my own life, to see those objects accomplished— I found him averse to the building of the Temple upon the Lot given by my father to the Town— Of this there may be further consideration— I spent the Evening till Midnight with George in Conversation upon my own early life, and his prospects and conduct, and those of his brothers— His health is yet very precarious, and his complaints various, complicated, and distressing— May they be removed.
25. VI. To the Woodlands.

Belated rising— My Son George though yet far from well, went to Boston in the Stage this Morning. I was occupied in examining antient family papers, and in drafting papers for the execution of my father’s Will, and with talking to Farrar, about the disposal of my farm for this winter and for the ensuing year. I propose to leave it this coming winter in his charge, and to give him a lease of it in the Spring— I found among the Mount Wollaston papers a copy of the proceedings of the Proprietors of the Town Lands; which may be useful in tracing the Lands apparent on my father’s Deeds which we have not yet been able to find— Mr Withington came about ten O’Clock, and Deacon Adams soon after— I sent to ask Captain Josiah Bass, and Peter Turner to go with us in to the Woods— Bass came about Noon. We examined again the Deeds, Withington’s Surveys, and the old Survey of Jedidiah Bass in 1785, till near one O’Clock—then took a light dinner, and went into the Woods— Peter Turner, and David Porter went with us— We had three parcels of Land to find— One Lot of more than eleven Acres, conveyed by Deed of the heirs of Benjamin Savil to John Adams 5. Octr. 1795— A Lot of about Six Acres contained in the Deed of Leonard Vassall Borland to John Adams of 6. Septr. 1787. and a difference of about seven Acres, between a survey of Jedidiah Bass in May 1785 of a lot partly purchased of Benjn Beale, and Withington’s second survey of the same land— We this day only surveyed and marked what according to the Deed of Savil’s heirs I think must be the eleven Acre lot, in doing which we took in Land which has been divided between the Heirs of Peter Boylston Adams— We marked also what we took to be the six acre Borland lot; which the heirs of my uncle Peter, have also divided among themselves, without title, but upon a mere report of a blind old man named Joseph Bass— We had not time to go upon the 20 Acre lot partly purchased of B. Beale— Farrar and William Pote went with us as Chain carriers— We returned about Sunset. Captain Bass and Deacon Adams came in and took Withington’s last Survey of the Quincy lot, for a reapprizement of it with Daniel Greenleaf to be returned to the judge of Probate. My Son John came out from Boston, just before we went into the Woods, and returned before we came back— My wife continues ill in bed at Boston— Elizabeth C. Adams has also been confined with a fever since the 21st. I removed for writing from the lower room to my bed-chamber, where I had a small furnace fire made, and wrote the whole Evening— The weather is far better for ranging in the woods, than it was in August—
26. V. Boston. Cambridge Boston.

Mr Greenleaf called and delivered to me the appraisement of the three additional Acres, found in the woodlot called the Quincy lot. Mr George Smith to request me to name him to General H. A. S. Dearborn the Collector at Boston for an appointment as Inspector of the customs— I spoke to Mr Greenleaf on the subject of the management of the farms, and made him proposals, which appeared acceptable to him— Numbers of people came to inspect the Articles to be sold at Auction to-morrow; and I had an unexpected interview with Mrs Barney Smith— I left the House about one, when all the visitors had departed, and came into Boston— I found my wife still extremely ill, confined with an inflammatory fever to her bed and attended by Dr Bigelow. Harriet Welsh was also with her— After sitting with her about an hour, I went to Cambridge, and dined with Mr T. Fuller, at the House which was formerly judge Davis’s, and which he has purchased. President Kirkland, Professors Ware and Willard, Messrs.Everett and Bailey, T. Welsh, and several others, were there, with Mrs Fuller and her daughter, and his Sister— After dinner he introduced to me two of his five Sons— I spoke to President Kirkland of Thomas J. Hellen, and recommended him to his charge. He had sent a message to that effect to my wife, who had requested me readily to accept it— Mr Fuller had invited evening company with the expectation of their meeting me there, and among the rest the daughters of the late judge Dana— But the illness of Mrs Adams, and the expectation that John would go this Evening out to Quincy compelled me to return to Boston before Mr Fuller’s evening company had arrived. John concluded however, to wait and go out to Quincy to-morrow Morning— I spent an hour of the Evening with my wife, at her bed side— There was a Mr David Pickering came yesterday to Quincy, to solicit subscriptions for a Baptist Church, and Education somewhere.

I forgot to mention the day of yesterday that Captain James Brackett came in the morning, and informed me that he had several Old Deeds of the Quincy Woodlands, which might assist me in my searches for my father’s Lots, and offered me the inspection of them— He also told me that he had an old plan of the 600 Acres as taken by Coll. Thaxter in the year 1700, from which the small one which I have is a reduced copy, made by him— He spoke to me also of my small lot of Saltmarsh bounding upon him, and of the boundary question which he wished settled— The difference he said amounted to about one Cock of Hay, and his claim rested on the fact that his fathers people had always mowed there— I told him I would readily settle the matter with him hereafter, being now wholly occupied in settling my father’s Estate— This morning my Son John went out to Quincy, to attend the Sale of furniture and farming Stock of my fathers Estate, this day and to-morrow. I marked the inventory, and authorised him to bid for me beyond the appraisement for almost every Article to be sold— Mr Cruft and judge Hall successively called and spent an hour with me— My Son George also came, having been with the Committee of the Legislature upon Railways; and they are going out to view that at Quincy to-morrow— I sat great part of the morning with my wife first at her bedside, and afterwards by the side of the Sopha to which she removed. I told her my dispositions for the future, after my seclusion from public life, which have the approbation of my own heart, and upon which I must hope for aid and encouragement, which the world will not give— I dined at Lieutenant Governor T. L. Winthrop’s, with a company of about 20. one of his daughters was the only Lady at table. Genl. H. Dearborn, Silsbee, Fuller, Everett, G. Blake, Austin, Gerry, Catlett, Myers, L. N. Rogers, T. Welsh, and some others were there— After dinner I called at Mr H. G. Otis’s but neither he, nor Mrs Otis was at home. I then went to Dr Welsh’s, and sat an hour with George, who is yet exceedingly feeble— Mrs Adams continues better— I signed Land-grants and wrote till near Midnight— Last Evening Coll. J. B. Davis came for my answer to a Letter of invitation from Governor Lincoln to attend the Cattle Show at Worcester the 11th. of next Month; and to dine with him on the 10th. I promised to answer it before Saturday.
28. IV. Cry of Fire— Charlestown. Boston. Sale at Quincy.

There was a false alarm of fire about two O’Clock this Morning; upon which I rose and came down to Mrs Adams’s chamber. She was awakened, but not much agitated and the bells soon ceased to ring. I returned to my bed, but could not sleep; and at four rose again to write— Dr Waterhouse called, and shewed me a Letter from my father to him, upon Locke, Hume, Dr Brown, Bishop Butler and others written in 1807. and full of matter— He asked also my advice with regard to the publication of a Letter from Mr Jefferson to him upon Religion— Mr Jefferson while living declined consenting to the publication, for fear of raising a hornet’s nest about his head— I advised the Doctor, to consult the grandson Jefferson Randolph— The Doctor also borrowed and brought me an old Manuscript Common Place Book of the Revd. John Hancock father of the late Governor. It belongs to Mr Snelling, President of the Fire and Marine Insurance Company.— I went this morning into the Stone Chapel, and examined the Monuments, which I found were three— One at the left hand of the front door on entering the Church, to Samuel Vassall a Patriot who suffered for refusing to pay Tonnage and Poundage in 1628. and was a member of Parliament in 1640. This monument was erected in 1766. by his great-grandson Florentius Vassall, of Jamaica, residing in England— One in a Wall pew at the right hand— A tablet with obituary inscriptions in Latin; to Frances Shirley, wife and Frances Bollan, daughter of Governor Shirley. The third in the opposite pew on the left side; erected to Charles Apthorp, by his widow and 15. children. He died in 1758. There is also over the left door of the vestry a simple inscription upon a black marble slab of William Price a benefactor of this Church—died 1772 aged 87— The Vassall monument is surmounted by a bust of the man. That to Mrs Shirley by her bust; but the Apthorp monument only by a weeping Genius and an Urn. The inscription upon the Shirley tablet is in elegant Latin, with well chosen and well concentrated topics of encomium— I called at Stuart the Painter’s, but he was abroad— I took up judge Hall at his House, and we went and dined with Edward Everett at Winter Hill, Charlestown— We returned to Boston about Sunset, as I intended to go out this Evening to Quincy— But my Son John came in so late, about nine O’Clock that I concluded to go out to-morrow Morning. The Sale began yesterday, and was finished this afternoon. Most of the furniture and stock was purchased for me.
29. IV.— Quincy.

I slept little, rose at four and wrote till breakfast time— Mr Brown the Broker brought me a certificate of 13. Shares in the Middlesex Canal— Mrs Adams, who is better spoke of leaving the City next Monday to return to Washington— Thinking she will not then have sufficiently recovered her strength, I mentioned to Dr Bigelow, the state of nervous irritation which forms her principal disease, and the causes by which it is at this time moved—and desired him to dissuade her from going sooner than would be prudent— I then came out with William to Quincy; stopped on the way at Mr Withington’s, and took the plans of his last surveys; leaving a request that he would send his bill— I also stopped at the Railway, and agreed with Coll. Perkins, whom I found at Jonathan Beale’s door, to meet him and view the Railway with him next Thursday morning at ten— On reaching home, I found the house emptied of much of its furniture, and in some disorder— Deacon Spear much occupied in delivering the Articles sold— I resumed the drafting of papers for the Execution of my fathers Will, which are numerous— My Son George is here having come out yesterday to view the Railway with Dr Phelps and Mr Washburn members with him of a Committee of the Legislature— In the afternoon Mr Withington came and brought his account for surveying, which I paid him— I told him I should probably wish him to make further surveys to discover the land which we have not yet found— After writing till the dusk of Evening, I called on Mr Thomas Greenleaf, and conversed with him upon the dispositions to be made of the Temple and School fund, instituted by my father. Mentioned the Act of Incorporation of the Supervisors, which I had drafted, and given to my brother, and my wishes with regard to the erection of the Temple, the first of the objects contemplated by my father which it may be practicable to accomplish— I wished it might be built on the lot given by him to the town; but the objections against this are so great that it probably cannot be effected. The lot however will remain for the Academy building— The rest of the Evening I spent in conversation with George who is recovering from his illness. Mr Perez Morton and his wife called this morning— I enquired of them if they knew the writer of the Latin obituary Inscription upon the Monument in the Stone Chapel, to the wife and daughter of Governor Shirley, but they did not. That on the monument of Charles Apthorp, they said was written by his Son East Apthorp. Mr and Mrs Morton after a life of many vicissitudes, and storms, are now both beyond the verge of seventy, and both looking remarkably well— They have both possessed talents that adorn life: and have survived errors and disasters, such as human nature seldom can sustain.
30. V: Boston— Watertown— Quincy.

Mr Richardson a Clergyman of Hingham came to intercede in behalf of a Mrs Amedy, for the pardon of her husband convicted before the Circuit Court of the United States at Richmond, Virginia, for scuttling a vessel of which he was master, and sentence of Death upon whom is suspended upon some question of Law in the case. I told him the application would be duly considered, when it would be the duty of the Executive to decide upon it— Peter Turner, brought here several old Deeds of Woodlands which belonged to his Grandfather, my Uncle Peter Boylston Adams, which may partly serve to clear up the question of boundaries between them and my father’s Lands— Mr Dunbar is one of the Teachers in Captain Partridge’s Military Academy at Middletown, and called here with Mr Tewksbury, merely on a visit of curiosity. Spear, Greenleaf and Whitney were here to proceed in the Settlement of Accounts of the sale of furniture and Stock— I continued making the drafts of Deeds and papers for the Settlement of my father’s Estate—upon which my brother is likewise occupied. After one I went with William in to Boston, and found Mrs Adams at dinner, with my Son John, and Thomas J. Hellen. She is much recovered and now proposes to go homeward, about the middle of next week. I went to dine with Mr Nathanael Amory at Watertown, but missed the way, and did not reach his house till five O’Clock, when I found him and his company at the Dessert. Mrs Amory and Miss Elwyn were at the table. J. Welles, T. H. Perkins, Charles and B. Joy, J. Callender, W. Sullivan, I. P. Davis, and some others were there—the remnants of an old Saturday’s club, of which I was an associate from 1791. to 1794— We sat recounting the tales of other times till about nine in the Evening after which I returned with William to Quincy; about 18 Miles— I reached home as the Clock struck 11.

Day. The month like the two preceding ones has been chiefly devoted to the Settlement of my father’s Estate— As the Sun rises later my hour of rising has dallied correspondingly, and I have passed several days in Boston, though not altogether idle— I have prepared in great measure for myself a place of retirement from March 1829. for the remainder of my days, and when that day comes, if indulged with health and peace, I trust it will find me ready and willing to renounce the vain pomp and tumult of the world, and finish my life with an employment of Time, worthy of that which has engaged my youth and mature years—
